message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Nonreciprocal Ising Model
Paper Abstract: Systems with nonreciprocal interactions generically display time-dependent states. These are routinely observed in finite systems, from neuroscience to active matter, in which globally ordered oscillations exist. However, the stability of these uniform nonreciprocal phases in noisy spatially-extended systems, their fate in the thermodynamic limit, and the critical behavior of the corresponding phase transitions are not fully understood. Here, we address these questions by introducing a nonreciprocal generalization of the Ising model and study its phase transitions by means of numerical and analytical approaches. While the mean-field equations predict three stable homogeneous phases (disordered, ordered, and a time-dependent swap phase), our large scale numerical simulations reveal a more complex picture. Static order is destroyed in any finite dimension due to the growth of rare droplets unless the symmetry between the two spin types is broken, triggering a stabilizing droplet-capture mechanism. The swap phase is destroyed by fluctuations in two dimensions through the proliferation of spiral defects but stabilized in three dimensions, where nonreciprocity changes the critical exponents from Ising to XY, thus giving rise to a robust spatially-distributed clock.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Mean-field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical mean-field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_mean-field_theory"},{"title":"Mean-field game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_game_theory"},{"title":"Polymer field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polymer_field_theory"},{"title":"Field (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_(physics)"},{"title":"Field-theoretic simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-theoretic_simulation"},{"title":"Ring (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Identity type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_type"},{"title":"Algebraic quantum field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_quantum_field_theory"},{"title":"Effective theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effective_theory"}]

Here are the search results for Mean Field Theory:

## Overview

Mean-field theory (MFT) or Self-consistent field theory studies the behavior of high-dimensional random (stochastic) models by studying a simpler model that approximates the original by averaging over degrees of freedom.

## Core Concept

The main idea of MFT is to replace all interactions to any one body with an average or effective interaction, sometimes called a molecular field, which reduces any many-body problem into an effective one-body problem.

## Key Advantages

The ease of solving MFT problems means that some insight into the behavior of the system can be obtained at a lower computational cost.

## Applications

MFT has since been applied to a wide range of fields outside of physics, including statistical inference, graphical models, neuroscience, artificial intelligence, epidemic models, queueing theory, and computer-network performance.

## Variations and Extensions

In a variant of mean field theory called dynamical mean field theory (DMFT), the mean field becomes a time-dependent quantity.(no content)DMFT is a method to determine the electronic structure of strongly correlated materials.

## Limitations

In general, dimensionality plays an active role in determining whether a mean-field approach will work for any particular problem. There is sometimes a critical dimension above which MFT is valid and below which it is not.

Links: [{"title":"Classical XY model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model"},{"title":"Kosterlitz–Thouless transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosterlitz–Thouless_transition"},{"title":"Nicolet 1080 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolet_1080"},{"title":"Ford Falcon (XY) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Falcon_(XY)"},{"title":"Cutter location - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutter_location"},{"title":"Universality class - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about the XY model:

## Overview

The classical XY model (sometimes also called classical rotor (rotator) model or O(2) model) is a lattice model of statistical mechanics.(no content)In general, the XY model can be seen as a specialization of Stanley's n-vector model for n = 2.(no content)The XY model is a two-dimensional vector spin model that possesses U(1) or circular symmetry.

## Phase Transitions

The behavior of the XY model varies significantly depending on dimensionality:

- **One dimension**: In one dimension the XY model does not have a phase transition

- **Two dimensions**: In two dimensions it has the Berezinski-Kosterlitz-Thouless transition between the phases with exponentially and powerlaw decaying correlation functions.(no content)The Berezinskii–Kosterlitz–Thouless (BKT) transition is a phase transition of the two-dimensional XY model in statistical physics. It is a transition from bound vortex-antivortex pairs at low temperatures to unpaired vortices and anti-vortices at some critical temperature.

- **Three and higher dimensions**: In three and higher dimensions the XY model has a ferromagnet-paramagnet phase transition.(no content)Many three-dimensional physical systems belong to the same universality class as the three dimensional XY model and share the same critical exponents, most notably easy-plane magnets and liquid Helium-4.

Cristina Marchetti - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M._Cristina_Marchetti"},{"title":"Vicsek model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vicsek_model"},{"title":"John Toner (physicist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Toner_(physicist)"},{"title":"Hans Elsässer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Els%C3%A4sser"},{"title":"Category:Soft matter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Soft_matter"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Peer review/Bash.org/archive1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Peer_review/Bash.org/archive1"},{"title":"Template talk:Episode list - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Episode_list"}]

## Active Matter

Active matter is matter composed of large numbers of active "agents", each of which consumes energy in order to move or to exert mechanical forces.(no content)Such systems are intrinsically out of thermal equilibrium.

### Characteristics

Active matter systems break time reversal symmetry because energy is being continually dissipated by the individual constituents. This fundamental property distinguishes active matter from passive systems in equilibrium.

### Examples

Most examples of active matter are biological in origin and span all the scales of the living, from bacteria and self-organising bio-polymers such as microtubules and actin (both of which are part of the cytoskeleton of living cells), to schools of fish and flocks of birds.(no content)However, a great deal of current experimental work is devoted to synthetic systems such as artificial self-propelled particles.

### Research and Models

Active matter is a relatively new material classification in soft matter: the most extensively studied model, the Vicsek model, dates from 1995.(no content)The Vicsek model consists of point-like self-propelled particles that evolve at constant speed and align their velocity with their neighbours' one in presence of noise.(no content)Research in active matter combines analytical techniques, numerical simulations and experiments, with notable analytical approaches including hydrodynamics, kinetic theory, and non-equilibrium statistical physics.

Most examples of active matter are biological in origin and span all the scales of the living, from bacteria and self-organising bio-polymers such as microtubules and actin (both of which are part of the cytoskeleton of living cells), to schools of fish and flocks of birds.(no content)However, a great deal of current experimental work is devoted to synthetic systems such as artificial self-propelled particles.

### Research and Models

Active matter is a relatively new material classification in soft matter: the most extensively studied model, the Vicsek model, dates from 1995.(no content)The Vicsek model consists of point-like self-propelled particles that evolve at constant speed and align their velocity with their neighbours' one in presence of noise.(no content)Research in active matter combines analytical techniques, numerical simulations and experiments, with notable analytical approaches including hydrodynamics, kinetic theory, and non-equilibrium statistical physics.

Links: [{"title":"Topological defect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_defect"},{"title":"Talk:Topological defect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Topological_defect"},{"title":"Texture (cosmology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texture_(cosmology)"},{"title":"Sinéad Griffin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sin%C3%A9ad_Griffin"},{"title":"Crystallographic defect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystallographic_defects"},{"title":"Tom Kibble - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_W._B._Kibble"},{"title":"Homotopy colimit and limit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homotopy_colimit_and_limit"},{"title":"Domenica Garzón - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domenica_Garz%C3%B3n"}]

## Topological Defect

In mathematics and physics, solitons, topological solitons and topological defects are three closely related ideas, all of which signify structures in a physical system that are stable against perturbations.(no content)Topological defects are not only stable against small perturbations, but cannot decay or be undone or be de-tangled, precisely because there is no continuous transformation that will map them (homotopically) to a uniform or "trivial" solution.(no content)The existence of a topological defect can be demonstrated whenever the boundary conditions entail the existence of homotopically distinct solutions, typically because the boundary on which the conditions are specified has a non-trivial homotopy group which is preserved in differential equations.(no content)Topological defects are regions in a crystal where the normal chemical bonding environment is topologically different from the surroundings.

### Types and Applications

Topological defects include monopoles, cosmic strings and domain walls that can be formed through mechanisms of symmetry breaking and phase transitions.(no content)Topological defects occur in partial differential equations and are believed to drive phase transitions in condensed matter physics.(no content)In cosmology, a texture is a type of topological defect in the order parameter (typically a scalar field) of a field theory featuring spontaneous symmetry breaking.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model"},{"title":"Square lattice Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_lattice_Ising_model"},{"title":"Transverse-field Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse-field_Ising_model"},{"title":"High-dimensional Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-dimensional_Ising_model"},{"title":"Two-dimensional critical Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-dimensional_critical_Ising_model"},{"title":"Ising critical exponents","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"},{"title":"Ernst Ising - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Ising"},{"title":"Construction of an irreducible Markov chain in the Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construction_of_an_irreducible_Markov_chain_in_the_Ising_model"},{"title":"Spherical model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_model"},{"title":"Swendsen–Wang algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swendsen%E2%80%93Wang_algorithm"}]

## Ising Model

The Ising model, named after the physicists Ernst Ising and Wilhelm Lenz, is a mathematical model of ferromagnetism in statistical mechanics.(no content)The model consists of discrete variables that represent magnetic dipole moments of atomic "spins" that can be in one of two states (+1 or −1).

### Structure and Interactions

The spins are arranged in a graph, usually a lattice (where the local structure repeats periodically in all directions), allowing each spin to interact with its neighbors.(no content)Neighboring spins that agree have a lower energy than those that disagree; the system tends to the lowest energy but heat disturbs this tendency, thus creating the possibility of different structural phases.

### Historical Development

The Ising model was invented by the physicist Wilhelm Lenz (1920), who gave it as a problem to his student Ernst Ising.(no content)The one-dimensional Ising model was solved by Ising (1925) alone in his 1924 thesis; it has no phase transition.(no content)The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is much harder and was only given an analytic description much later, by Lars Onsager (1944).

### Physical Significance

The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is one of the simplest statistical models to show a phase transition.(no content)Though it is a highly simplified model of a magnetic material, the Ising model can still provide qualitative and sometimes quantitative results applicable to real physical systems.

## Critical Exponent

The search returned information about critical exponents in physics. Here's an overview:

### Physics Definition

Critical exponents describe the behavior of physical quantities near continuous phase transitions.(no content)It is believed, though not proven, that they are universal—they do not depend on the details of the physical system, but only on some of its general features.

### Key Characteristics

These exponents are robust observables that take the same values for very different physical systems.(no content)Critical phenomena include scaling relations among different quantities, power-law divergences of some quantities (such as the magnetic susceptibility in the ferromagnetic phase transition) described by critical exponents.

### Evaluation Methods

Critical exponents can be evaluated via Monte Carlo methods of lattice models, and the most widely applicable technique is the renormalization group.

### Mathematical Context

There is also a separate meaning in computer science: In mathematics and computer science, the critical exponent of a finite or infinite sequence of symbols over a finite alphabet describes the largest number of times a contiguous subsequence can be repeated.

The search returned information about critical exponents in physics. Here's an overview:

### Physics Definition

Critical exponents describe the behavior of physical quantities near continuous phase transitions.(no content)It is believed, though not proven, that they are universal—they do not depend on the details of the physical system, but only on some of its general features.

### Key Characteristics

These exponents are robust observables that take the same values for very different physical systems.(no content)Critical phenomena include scaling relations among different quantities, power-law divergences of some quantities (such as the magnetic susceptibility in the ferromagnetic phase transition) described by critical exponents.

### Evaluation Methods

Critical exponents can be evaluated via Monte Carlo methods of lattice models, and the most widely applicable technique is the renormalization group.

### Mathematical Context

There is also a separate meaning in computer science: In mathematics and computer science, the critical exponent of a finite or infinite sequence of symbols over a finite alphabet describes the largest number of times a contiguous subsequence can be repeated.

Links: [{"title":"Thermodynamic efficiency limit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermodynamic_efficiency_limit"},{"title":"Thermodynamic limit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermodynamic_limit"},{"title":"Thermal efficiency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermal_efficiency"},{"title":"Landauer's principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landauer's_principle"},{"title":"Carnot's theorem (thermodynamics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnot's_theorem_(thermodynamics)"},{"title":"Heat death of the universe - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_death_of_the_universe"},{"title":"Random generalized Lotka–Volterra model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_generalized_Lotka%E2%80%93Volterra_model"},{"title":"Thermotoga maritima - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermotoga_maritima"},{"title":"Maximum entropy thermodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_entropy_thermodynamics"},{"title":"Talk:Bethe lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Bethe_lattice"}]

## Thermodynamic Limit

Based on the search results, here's information about the thermodynamic limit:

In statistical mechanics, the thermodynamic limit or macroscopic limit of a system is the limit for a large number N of particles (e.g., atoms or molecules) where the volume V is taken to grow in proportion with the number of particles.

### Key Characteristics

In this limit, macroscopic thermodynamics is valid. There, thermal fluctuations in global quantities are negligible, and all thermodynamic quantities, such as pressure and energy, are simply functions of the thermodynamic variables, such as temperature and density.(no content)The thermodynamic limit is essentially a consequence of the central limit theorem of probability theory. The internal energy of a gas of N molecules is the sum of order N contributions, each of which is approximately independent, and so the central limit theorem predicts that the ratio of the size of the fluctuations to the mean is of order 1/N^(1/2).

### Practical Relevance

In general, almost all macroscopic volumes of gases, liquids and solids can be treated as being in the thermodynamic limit.(no content)It is at the thermodynamic limit that the additivity property of macroscopic extensive variables is obeyed. That is, the entropy of two systems or objects taken together (in addition to their energy and volume) is the sum of the two separate values.

### Limitations

It's worth noting that a thermodynamic limit does not exist in all cases.(no content)For example, particles with an attractive potential that doesn't turn around and become repulsive even at very short distances can cause problems. This is the case for gravitational systems, where matter tends to clump into filaments, galactic superclusters, galaxies, stellar clusters and stars.

Links: [{"title":"Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_transition"},{"title":"Cosmological phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmological_phase_transition"},{"title":"Superradiant phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superradiant_phase_transition"},{"title":"Rapid phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapid_phase_transition"},{"title":"Quantum phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_phase_transition"},{"title":"Sublimation (phase transition) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sublimation_(phase_transition)"},{"title":"Deposition (phase transition) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deposition_(phase_transition)"},{"title":"Phase change - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_change"},{"title":"Phase Transitions and Critical Phenomena - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_Transitions_and_Critical_Phenomena"},{"title":"Talk:Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Phase_transition"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about phase transitions:

## Definition and Basic Concept

In physics, chemistry and biology, a phase transition (or phase change) is the physical process of transition between one state of a medium and another.(no content)A phase transition usually occurs when the pressure or temperature changes and the system crosses from one region to another, like water turning from liquid to solid as soon as the temperature drops below the freezing point.

## States of Matter

Commonly the term is used to refer to changes among the basic states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas, and in rare cases, plasma.(no content)During a phase transition of a given medium, certain properties of the medium change as a result of the change of external conditions, such as temperature or pressure. This can be a discontinuous change; for example, a liquid may become gas upon heating to its boiling point, resulting in an abrupt change in volume.

## Types of Phase Transitions

**Between States of Matter:** Sublimation is the transition of a substance directly from the solid to the gas state, without passing through the liquid state.(no content)Deposition is the phase transition in which gas transforms into solid without passing through the liquid phase.

**Structural Changes:** Phase transitions can also occur when a solid changes to a different structure without changing its chemical makeup. In elements, this is known as allotropy, whereas in compounds it is known as polymorphism. The change from one crystal structure to another, from a crystalline solid to an amorphous solid, or from one amorphous structure to another (polyamorphs) are all examples of solid to solid phase transitions.

**Magnetic Transitions:** Phase transitions can also describe the change between different kinds of magnetic ordering. The most well-known is the transition between the ferromagnetic and paramagnetic phases of magnetic materials, which occurs at what is called the Curie point.

**Quantum Phase Transitions:** A quantum phase transition (QPT) is a phase transition between different quantum phases (phases of matter at zero temperature). Contrary to classical phase transitions, quantum phase transitions can only be accessed by varying a physical parameter—such as magnetic field or pressure—at absolute zero temperature.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the "Nonreciprocal Ising Model" paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Analysis Results:**
The paper proposes a nonreciprocal generalization of the Ising model and studies its phase transitions. I identified and documented 8 key triples:

1. **Ising model** (concept) - Proposed: The paper introduces a novel nonreciprocal variant
2. **Phase transition** (concept) - Uses: Studied via numerical and analytical methods
3. **Mean-field theory** (method) - Uses: Applied to predict stable homogeneous phases
4. **Classical XY model** (concept) - Uses: Critical exponents transition from Ising to XY class
5. **Critical exponent** (concept) - Uses: Characterized changes due to nonreciprocity
6. **Thermodynamic limit** (concept) - Uses: Analyzes behavior in the limit of large systems
7. **Active matter** (concept) - Uses: Context where nonreciprocal interactions with oscillations occur
8. **Topological defect** (concept) - Proposed: Discovers spiral defects that destroy phases in 2D

**Validation Status:** ✅ **PASSED** - All checks passed successfully with proper Wikipedia URLs and entity types.

The triples_output.json file has been updated with all entities, their relationships to the paper, entity classifications, relevant Wikipedia links, and explanations of their significance.

Sources:
- [Ising model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model)
- [Phase transition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_transition)
- [Mean-field theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_theory)
- [Classical XY model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model)
- [Critical exponent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_exponent)
- [Thermodynamic limit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermodynamic_limit)
- [Active matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_matter)
- [Topological defect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_defect)
